alert.description: A message with important, and usually time-sensitive, information. Also see alertdialog and status.

alertdialog.description: A type of dialog that contains an alert message, where initial focus goes to the dialog or an element within it. Also see alert and dialog.

alternate.description: alternate designates alternate versions for a resource.

appendix.description: appendix refers to a resource serving as an appendix in a collection.

application.description: A region declared as a web application, as opposed to a web document.

article.description: A section of a page consisting of an independent part of a document, page, or site.

banner.description: banner contains the prime heading or internal title of a page.

bookmark.description: bookmark refers to a bookmark - a link to a key entry point within an extended document.

button.description: An input that allows for user-triggered actions when clicked or pressed.

chapter.description: chapter refers to a resource serving as a chapter in a collction.

checkbox.description: An checkable input that has three possible values: true, false, or mixed.

cite.description: cite refers to a resource that defines a citation.

columnheader.description: A cell containing header information for a column.

combobox.description: A presentation of a select; usually similar to a textbox where users can type ahead to select an option, or type to enter arbitrary text as a new item in the list.

complementary.description: secondary indicates that the section supports but is separable from the main content of resource.

contentinfo.description: contentinfo has meta information about the content on the page or the page as a whole.

contents.description: contents refers to a resource serving as a table of contents.

copyright.description: copyright refers to a copyright statement for the resource.

definition.description: definition indicates the definition of a term or concept.

dialog.description: A dialog is an application window that is designed to interrupt the current processing of an application in order to prompt the user to enter information or require a response. Also see alertdialog.

directory.description: A list of references to members of a group, such as a static table of contents.

document.description: A region containing related information that is declared as document content, as opposed to a web application.

first.description: first refers the first item in a collection (see also start and top).

glossary.description: glossary refers to a resource providing a glossary of terms.

grid.description: A grid contains cells of tabular data arranged in rows and columns, like a table.

gridcell.description: A cell in a grid or treegrid.

group.description: A set of user interface objects which would not be included in a page summary or table of contents by an assistive technology.

heading.description: A heading for a section of the page.

help.description: help refers to a resource offering help.

icon.description: icon refers to a resource that represents an icon.

img.description: A container for a collection of elements that form an image.

index.description: index refers to a resource providing an index.

itsRules.description: itsRules indicates that the designated resource is an [ITS] rule set.

last.description: last refers to the last resource in a collection of resources.

license.description: license refers to a resource that defines the associated license.

link.description: An interactive reference to an internal or external resource.

list.description: A group of non-interactive list items.

listbox.description: A widget that allows the user to select one or more items from a list of choices.

listitem.description: A single item in a list, listbox, or directory.

log.description: A type of live region where new information is added in meaningful order and old information may disappear. Also see marquee.

main.description: main acts as the main content of the document.

marquee.description: A type of live region where non-essential information changes frequently. Also see log.

math.description: An element that represents a mathematical expression.

menu.description: A type of widget that offers a list of choices to the user.

menubar.description: A presentation of menu that usually remains visible and is usually presented horizontally.

menuitem.description: An option in a group of choices contained by a menu or menubar.

menuitemcheckbox.description: A checkable menuitem that has three possible values: true, false, or mixed.

menuitemradio.description: A checkable menuitem in a group of menuitemradio roles, only one of which can be checked at a time.

meta.description: meta refers to a resource that provides metadata.

navigation.description: navigation indicates a collection of items suitable for navigating the document or related documents.

next.description: next refers to the next resource (after the current one) in an ordered collection of resources.

note.description: note indicates the content is parenthetic or ancillary to the main content of the resource.

option.description: A selectable item in a select list.

p3pv1.description: p3pv1 refers to a P3P Policy Reference File [P3P].

presentation.description: An element whose role is presentational and does not need to be mapped to the accessibility API.

prev.description: prev refers to a previous resource (before the current one) in an ordered collection of resources.

progressbar.description: An element that displays the progress status for tasks that take a long time.

radio.description: A checkable input in a group of radio roles, only one of which can be checked at a time.

region.description: A large perceivable section of a web page or document, that the author feels should be included in a summary of page features.

role.description: role indicates the purpose of the resource. See the XHTML Role Vocabulary for roles in this vocabulary space, and XHTMLROLE for information on extending the collection of roles.

row.description: A row of cells in a grid.

rowheader.description: A cell containing header information for a row in a grid.

search.description: search indicates that the section provides a search facility.

section.description: section refers to a resource serving as a section in a collection.

separator.description: A divider that separates and distinguishes sections of content or groups of menuitems.

slider.description: A user input where the user selects a value from within a given range.

spinbutton.description: A form of range that expects a user to select from amongst discrete choices.

start.description: start refers to the first resource in a collection of resources.

status.description: A container whose content is advisory information for the user but is not important enough to justify an alert. Also see alert.

stylesheet.description: stylesheet refers to a resource serving as a stylesheet for a resource.

subsection.description: subsection refers to a resource serving as a subsection in a collection.

tablist.description: A list of tab elements, which are references to tabpanel elements.

tabpanel.description: A container for the resources associated with a tab.

textbox.description: Input that allows free-form text as their value.

timer.description: A numerical counter which indicates an amount of elapsed time from a start point, or the time remaining until an end point.

toolbar.description: A collection of commonly used function buttons represented in compact visual form.

tooltip.description: A contextual popup that displays a description for an element in a mouse hover or keyboard focused state. Supplement to the normal tooltip processing of the user agent.

top.description: top is a synonym for start.

tree.description: A type of list that may contain sub-level nested groups that can be collapsed and expanded.

treegrid.description: A grid whose rows can be expanded and collapsed in the same manner as for a tree.

treeitem.description: An option item of a tree. This is an element within a tree that may be expanded or collapsed if it contains a sub-level group of treeitems.

up.description: up refers to a resource "above" in a hierarchically structured set.
